S. Alexander Jacobson wrote:

>Here is a more basic question:
>Why is authentication part of the HTTP
>specification at all?
>
>You can always generate single-use or secret URLs
>for applications that need them.
>  
>
Obscurity is generally understood to be a poor security mechanism (at 
least when used as the only mechanism).

>And if the issue is sharing information, that
>would come under the scope of people mailing each
>other the information as well...
>
>What are the actual use-cases for HTTP-auth?
>  
>
I publish a page on a web site that only certain people are allowed to 
see.  How do I restrict access to that page?  If HTTP is the protocol 
used to access resources, then it has to provide some mechanism for 
controlling access.  Where else would you suggest putting the access 
control mechanism?

--Chuck
